title: Support Dolt databases alongside SQLite
description:
Detect whether the backing store is a Dolt database or SQLite and use the appropriate driver.

## Context

bd-eye currently assumes a SQLite database via better-sqlite3 (synchronous, readonly WAL mode). Beads itself supports Dolt as a backend. bd-eye should be able to read from either.

## Detection strategy

- If the resolved path is a directory containing a `.dolt` subdirectory, treat as Dolt
- If the resolved path is a `.db` file, treat as SQLite
- The `BEADS_DB` env var and auto-discovery logic in `resolveDbPath()` already resolve to a path — detection layers on top of that

## Implementation plan

### 1. Make the Db interface async

The `Db` typedef in `src/server/db.js` (line 41-53) currently returns synchronous values. All methods need to return `Promise<T>` to support both sync (better-sqlite3) and async (mysql2) drivers.

**Files affected:**
- `src/server/db.js` — change typedef, wrap better-sqlite3 calls in `Promise.resolve()` or use `async` functions
- `src/server/routes/issues.js` — add `await` to every `db.*()` call, make route handlers `async`
- `src/server/index.js` — `await openDb()` at startup

### 2. Extract SQLite implementation

Move the current better-sqlite3 implementation into `src/server/db-sqlite.js`, exporting a function with the same `openDb` signature that returns a `Db`.

### 3. Create Dolt implementation

New file `src/server/db-dolt.js`:
- Connect to Dolt SQL server via `mysql2/promise`
- Implement the same `Db` interface
- Connection config from env vars: `DOLT_HOST`, `DOLT_PORT`, `DOLT_USER`, `DOLT_PASSWORD`, `DOLT_DATABASE`
- The SQL queries are standard and should transfer directly
- Views `ready_issues` and `blocked_issues` must exist in the Dolt schema (beads creates these)

### 4. Add detection and factory in db.js

`src/server/db.js` becomes a thin dispatcher:
- `resolveDbPath()` — unchanged
- `detectDbType(path)` — returns `'sqlite' | 'dolt'` based on path characteristics
- `openDb(path)` — calls the appropriate implementation

### 5. Adapt the file watcher

`src/server/watcher.js` currently watches SQLite WAL/SHM files via chokidar. For Dolt:
- Option A: Poll `DOLT_LOG()` or `HASHOF('HEAD')` on an interval to detect commits
- Option B: Watch the `.dolt/noms` directory for file changes
- Extract a `createWatcher(dbType, path, onChange)` factory

### 6. Update configuration

- Add new env vars to `.env.example`: `DOLT_HOST`, `DOLT_PORT`, `DOLT_USER`, `DOLT_PASSWORD`, `DOLT_DATABASE`
- Update README with Dolt setup instructions
- Add `mysql2` as an optional/peer dependency

## Key risks

- The sync-to-async migration touches every route handler — keep the diff minimal by making SQLite impl async too
- Dolt SQL server must be running separately — document this clearly
- Views (`ready_issues`, `blocked_issues`) must exist in Dolt — verify beads creates them for Dolt backends

title: Throughput chart
description: Chart showing issues closed over time. The closed_at timestamp already exists on issues
design:
## Visual Design: Stacked Bar Chart with Moving Average

### Concept
Stacked colour-coded bars (task=blue, feature=purple, bug=red, epic=orange) with a cubic-bezier moving average overlay line. Each bar segment has a vertical gradient fade for depth on dark background. Not a boring flat bar chart.

### Key Visual Elements

- **Stacked bars**: One per time bucket, segments stacked by issue type. Vertical gradient (full → 55% opacity) gives subtle depth
- **Moving average line**: 3-period rolling average as smooth cubic bezier curve in accent blue at 70% opacity, with small circles at data points
- **Bar glow on hover**: SVG `feGaussianBlur` + `feMerge` filter brightens hovered bar. Non-matching types dim to 18% opacity
- **Responsive via ResizeObserver**: SVG redraws at container width. Height clamped to 35% aspect ratio
- **X-axis label thinning**: Labels printed every N bars, scaling with bucket count
- **Type breakdown panel**: Below chart, each type gets a row with mini sparkline (80x28 SVG), count, and percentage bar

### Component Structure

\`\`\`
ThroughputChart            — root, owns state, fetches issues
  StatCard                 — individual stat (total, avg, best, trend)
  TypeLegend               — pill buttons to filter-highlight types
  BucketToggle             — Day | Week | Month segmented control
  SvgChart                 — pure SVG, all data as props
    <defs>                 — gradients + glow filter
    y-tick lines + labels
    bar <g> groups         — stacked <rect> segments + x-label
    moving average <path> + <circle> points
  Tooltip                  — absolute-positioned HTML overlay
  TypeBreakdownRow (x4)    — sparkline + bar + count per type
    MiniSparkline          — tiny 80x28 SVG area fill + bezier + end dot
\`\`\`

### Bucketing Logic

\`buildBuckets(issues, granularity)\` pure function:
1. Filter to issues with \`closed_at\` non-null
2. Compute bucket key: \`YYYY-MM-DD\` (daily), ISO Monday week-start (weekly), \`YYYY-MM\` (monthly)
3. Accumulate into \`Map<key, { task, bug, feature, epic, total }>\`
4. Return sorted by key

Granularity switchable via BucketToggle; re-runs via \`useMemo\`.

### Summary Statistics

| Stat | Computation |
|---|---|
| Total closed | Sum of all bucket totals |
| Avg/period | totalClosed / buckets.length |
| Best period | Bucket with highest total |
| Trend | Last 3 avg vs prior 3 avg, signed % |
| Periods | buckets.length |

Trend suppressed when < 4 buckets.

### SVG Techniques

- \`linearGradient\` with vertical fade per bar segment
- Cubic bezier path for moving average (midpoint control points)
- \`feGaussianBlur\` + \`feMerge\` filter for hover glow in \`<defs>\`
- \`transition: opacity 150ms ease\` on bar groups for type-dim animation
- Bar width: \`Math.max(2, Math.min(40, innerW / n - 3))\`
- Tooltip flips left when it would overflow right edge

### Interactions

- Hover bar → glow + tooltip with date, total, per-type breakdown
- Hover legend pill → dim all bars except that type across entire chart
- Click BucketToggle → re-bucket data (Day/Week/Month)
- Moving average dots enlarge on nearby bar hover
close_reason: Throughput chart implemented with stacked bars, moving average, type breakdown sparklines

title: Add test suite with 85% minimum coverage
description:
The project currently has zero tests. Add a comprehensive test suite targeting at least 85% code coverage.

## Scope

Server-side code in src/server/:

- **db.js**: detectDbType() path classification (sqlite vs dolt), resolveDbPath() env var / auto-discovery / fallback behaviour, openDb() factory dispatching
- **db-sqlite.js**: All Db interface methods (allIssues, issueById, readyIssues, blockedIssues, dependenciesFor, epics, epicChildren, labels, commentsFor, allLabels, searchIssues, close) against a temp SQLite database
- **db-dolt.js**: Same Db interface methods — will need a mock or integration test against a real Dolt SQL server
- **routes/issues.js**: Response shapes, query param filtering, 404 handling, label attachment via attachLabels()
- **watcher.js**: createWatcher() factory dispatching, SQLite watcher triggers on file change, Dolt watcher polls and detects hash changes
- **index.js**: Startup wiring (may be covered by integration tests)

## Approach

- Pick a test runner (vitest recommended — fast, ESM-native, built-in coverage via c8/v8)
- Use parameterized tests where possible
- Use a temp SQLite database for db-sqlite and route tests
- Mock mysql2/promise for db-dolt unit tests
- Add npm scripts: test, test:coverage
- Configure coverage thresholds: 85% minimum for lines, branches, functions, statements
- Add coverage config to vitest.config.js or package.json

title: Activity feed
description: Show recent status changes across the project with timestamps. The data (created_at, updated_at, closed_at) already exists on issues
design:
## Visual Design: Vertical Timeline Feed

A left-edge timeline with a continuous connector line and coloured status dots. Compact horizontal rows: dot | type glyph | mono ID | title (truncated) | status transition badges | timestamp.

### Key Visual Elements

- **Timeline bar**: 2px vertical line in `--color-border` with gradient fade toward bottom
- **Status dots**: 10px coloured circles — blue=opened, amber=in-progress, grey=closed. Top dot pulses via `box-shadow` keyframe
- **Type glyphs**: Unicode characters — ⬤ task, ⬡ bug, ◈ feature, ◆ epic — coloured by `--color-type-*` vars
- **Status transition**: From→to badge pairs (e.g. `open › in-progress`) reusing existing `.badge` classes. The `from` badge at 0.6 opacity
- **Slide-in animation**: New entries animate from top with 200ms translate+opacity. Tracked via ref to only fire on genuinely new entries
- **Hover**: Left-border flash to `--color-accent-primary` + `--color-bg-tertiary` background

### Event Shape

```js
{
  id: 'BD-42',
  title: 'Fix login redirect loop',
  issue_type: 'bug',       // bug | feature | task | epic
  from: 'open',            // null when first opened
  to: 'in-progress',
  assignee: 'alice',       // nullable
  timestamp: '2026-02-19T14:23:00Z',
}
```

### Data Source

Derive events from existing issue fields: `created_at` → opened, `updated_at` + status → transition, `closed_at` → closed. No backend changes needed.

### Component Structure

- `ActivityFeed({ events, onSelectIssue, limit })` — container with header + scrollable list
- `FeedEntry({ event, isFirst, onClick })` — single timeline row
- `StatusTransition({ from, to })` — badge pair with arrow
- `relativeTime(dateStr)` — "3m ago", "2h ago", "1d ago" formatter

### CSS Highlights

- `.feed-list::before` pseudo-element draws the continuous timeline wire
- `.feed-dot` sits on wire via `z-index: 1`
- `.feed-title` uses `flex: 1; min-width: 0; text-overflow: ellipsis` for graceful truncation
- `@keyframes feed-pulse` on top dot only — `box-shadow` spread, no layout shift
- `@keyframes feed-slide-in` — one-shot entrance for new entries only
- Zero hardcoded colours — all via CSS custom properties
close_reason: Activity feed implemented with timeline view, status transitions, type glyphs, and relative timestamps

title: Project switcher
description:
Multi-project navigation allowing bd-eye to point at multiple beads databases and switch between them.

## Implementation Plan

### Architecture
One Dolt server serves multiple databases via `--data-dir`. bd-eye discovers valid beads databases via `SHOW DATABASES` + table validation. API routes gain a `/:project/` path segment. Connection pools are lazily created per database.

### Phase 1: Backend — Multi-Database Infrastructure

**Step 1: `src/server/db-registry.js`** (new)
- `Map<string, Db>` pool registry
- `connectionFor(name, baseConfig)` — returns cached or opens new via `openDoltDb`
- `closeAll()`, `openDbs()`

**Step 2: `src/server/routes/projects.js`** (new)
- `GET /api/projects` — `SHOW DATABASES`, filter system DBs, validate each has `issues` table
- Returns `{ projects: [{ name, issueCount }] }`

**Step 3: `src/server/routes/issues.js`** (modify)
- Change `issueRoutes(db)` to `issueRoutes(dbFor)`
- Add middleware: `c.set('db', await dbFor(c.req.param('project')))`
- All handlers change from closed-over `db` to `c.get('db')`

**Step 4: `src/server/index.js`** (modify)
- Wire registry, project routes, project-scoped issue routes
- Routes become: `/api/projects` and `/api/projects/:project/*`
- Shutdown calls `closeAll()`

**Step 5: `src/server/watcher.js`** (modify)
- Track `DOLT_HASHOF_DB()` per database name
- Broadcast includes project name in SSE data

**Step 6: `src/server/db.js`** (modify)
- Export `SYSTEM_DBS`

### Phase 2: Frontend — Project State and API Layer

**Step 7: `src/client/state.js`** (modify)
- Add signals: `currentProject`, `projectList`, `projectsLoading`
- Subscribe `currentProject` to localStorage (`bd-eye-project`)

**Step 8: `src/client/hooks/useProjects.js`** (new)
- Fetch `/api/projects`, populate signals
- Auto-select from localStorage or first alphabetically

**Step 9: `src/client/api.js`** (new)
- `apiUrl(path)` → `/api/projects/${currentProject.value}${path}`
- All components use this instead of hardcoded paths

**Step 10: `src/client/hooks/useIssues.js`** (modify)
- Use `apiUrl`, re-fetch when project changes

**Step 11: `src/client/hooks/useLiveUpdates.js`** (modify)
- Parse SSE event data, filter by `currentProject`

**Step 12: Update all direct fetch calls** — Board.jsx, DetailPanel.jsx, DependencyGraph.jsx, EpicExplorer.jsx, FilterBar.jsx, SearchModal.jsx → use `apiUrl`

### Phase 3: Frontend — Project Switcher Component

**Step 13: `src/client/components/ProjectSwitcher.jsx`** (new)
- 0 projects: "No projects found"
- 1 project: plain text, no interaction
- 2+ projects: dropdown with check mark, issue counts, keyboard nav
- Updates `document.title` on project change

**Step 14: `src/client/components/NavBar.jsx`** (modify)
- Insert ProjectSwitcher between app name and nav tabs

**Step 15: `src/client/components/App.jsx`** (modify)
- Call `useProjects()`, show skeleton while loading, empty state if no projects

### Phase 4: Styling

**Step 16: `src/styles/main.css`** — project switcher dropdown, active states, skeleton shimmer

### Phase 5: Testing

**Step 17:** `tests/db-registry.test.js` — pool caching, closeAll, openDbs
**Step 18:** `tests/routes-projects.test.js` — discovery, filtering, validation
**Step 19:** `tests/routes-issues.test.js` — update paths to project-scoped
**Step 20:** `tests/client/ProjectSwitcher.test.jsx` — single/multi/empty modes
**Step 21:** Update `tests/client/useIssues.test.jsx` — project-aware URLs
**Step 22:** Update `tests/client/NavBar.test.jsx` — ProjectSwitcher present

### Build Sequence
1. db.js (export SYSTEM_DBS) → 2. db-registry.js → 3. routes/projects.js → 4. routes/issues.js refactor → 5. index.js wiring → 6. watcher.js → 7-9. server tests → 10. state.js signals → 11. api.js helper → 12. useProjects.js → 13. useIssues.js → 14. useLiveUpdates.js → 15. update 7 components → 16. ProjectSwitcher.jsx → 17. NavBar.jsx → 18. App.jsx → 19. CSS → 20. client tests

### Key Decisions
- **Path prefix** `/api/projects/:project/` over query params — cleaner URLs, natural Hono routing
- **Lazy pool creation** — pools opened on first request, not at startup
- **Centralised `apiUrl` helper** — minimises file changes, reads from signal
- **SSE stays global** — one connection, client-side project filtering
design:
## Research Findings: Dolt Multi-Database Discovery

### Key Finding
One Dolt SQL server can serve multiple databases via directory-based discovery:
- `dolt sql-server` looks in its working directory and **one level of subdirectories** for `.dolt` directories
- Each directory containing `.dolt` becomes a separate database, named after the directory
- The `--data-dir` flag (or `data_dir` in YAML config) points the server at any parent directory
- `SHOW DATABASES` lists all available projects; `USE <database>` switches between them

### Implication for Project Switcher
The discovery problem dissolves — no process sniffing or port scanning needed:
1. One Dolt server started with `--data-dir` pointing at a parent containing beads project databases
2. `discoverDoltDatabase()` in db.js already does `SHOW DATABASES` — extend it to list all databases instead of erroring on multiple
3. Switching is a new connection pool with a different `database` field

---

## UX Design Spec

### Placement: Nav bar, between app name and nav links

```
[ Beady Eye ]  [ project-name ▾ ]  |  Board  Ready  Epics  Deps  Activity  Throughput  |  ⌘K
```

The project switcher is always visible — the current project is fundamental context.

### Current project display
- Muted but legible style, slightly less prominent than nav links
- Clickable with subtle border on hover
- **Single project**: plain text, no chevron, not interactive
- **Multi-project**: dropdown button with chevron

### Switching interaction
- **Click switcher** → small dropdown anchored below the button
- Current project has a check mark; arrow keys navigate, Enter selects, Escape closes
- No search input unless projects > 8 (then add filter input at top)
- **⌘K** also accepts project names as secondary path

### Loading/transition on switch
1. Project name updates immediately (optimistic)
2. Nav links gray out (pointer-events: none, opacity: 0.5)
3. Board shows skeleton/shimmer over existing column structure — cards replaced with placeholder bars
4. On data loaded: cards fade in ~150ms
- No full-page spinner — skeleton preserves spatial continuity

### First load behaviour
- Auto-select last-used project from `localStorage` key `bd-eye.lastProject`
- If stored project no longer valid, fall back to first alphabetically
- First ever visit: auto-select first project, show one-time toast: "Viewing project-name — switch projects from the top bar" (dismiss on click or after 4s)
- No interstitial picker — board renders immediately

### Empty state (no valid projects)
- Centred message: "No beads projects found" with explanation and Refresh button
- Nav bar renders but switcher slot empty, nav links grayed out

### Browser tab title
`project-name — Beady Eye` — updated on every switch

### Robustness
- Filter `SHOW DATABASES` to exclude system databases (information_schema, mysql, sys, performance_schema)
- Validate each candidate database has an `issues` table before listing
- Skip empty or non-beads databases gracefully

### Summary

| Concern | Decision |
|---|---|
| Placement | Nav bar, left of nav links |
| Single project | Plain text label, no interaction |
| Multi-project | Dropdown off the label button |
| ⌘K | Also accepts project switching, secondary path |
| Transition | Skeleton over existing board structure |
| First load | Auto-select last used, or first alphabetically |
| Empty state | Full board replaced, refresh button |
| Tab title | `project-name — Beady Eye` |

title: Board updated indicator
description: Subtle visual indicator when the board receives an SSE refresh, so the user knows data has changed. Currently the board silently re-renders which can be disorienting.
design:
## Implementation

### Approach: Status bar timestamp with fade-in highlight

A "Updated HH:MM:SS" timestamp in the bottom status bar that briefly brightens on each SSE refresh, then fades back to a dimmed resting state. Non-intrusive, never covers content, never requires dismissal.

### Behaviour
1. SSE refresh completes → timestamp updates to current time → colour jumps to active/bright state
2. After 800ms hold, transitions to resting state over 2200ms (total visible: 3s)
3. If another SSE fires mid-fade, animation resets from bright state
4. No user action required

### Visual spec (dark theme)
- Position: right-aligned in the status bar
- Font: 0.75rem, monospace/tabular numerals (no layout shift)
- Resting colour: `#4a5568` (muted grey, ~40% brightness)
- Active colour: `#68d391` (soft green, "data arrived" semantic)
- Transition: `color` property, `ease-out`, 2200ms fade-back
- Background: transparent, inherits status bar

### Integration
- After SSE-triggered board state update, set a signal/boolean that the StatusBar observes
- StatusBar stores last-updated Date and isHighlighted boolean
- On highlight: apply active CSS class, setTimeout 800ms to clear (CSS handles remaining fade)
- A module-level signal is sufficient, no global state manager needed

### Scope
- Shows THAT an update occurred, not WHAT changed
- Card-level diff animation is a separate, larger feature

### Files to change
- `src/client/main.css` — add `.status-updated` active and transition rules
- `src/client/state.js` — add `lastUpdated` signal
- `src/client/hooks/useLiveUpdates.js` — set lastUpdated on SSE refresh
- New or inline: `UpdatedAt` component in the status bar area
- `src/client/components/App.jsx` — render UpdatedAt in the layout
close_reason: Implemented: subtle timestamp in bottom-right that flashes green on SSE refresh, fades to muted grey

title: Board swimlanes
description: Group rows within each board column by assignee, epic, or label for better visual organisation
design:
## Visual Design Specification

### Layout Strategy: CSS Grid (row-major)
- `grid-template-columns: 220px repeat(3, 1fr)` — pinned row header + 3 column tracks
- Column headers as global grid headers with `position: sticky; top: var(--toolbar-height)` (z-index: 30)
- Row headers with `position: sticky; left: 0` (z-index: 20)
- Top-left corner cell sticky in both axes (z-index: 35) — houses Group-by control

### Group-By Control: Segmented Pill Group
- Horizontal pill group in the toolbar: None | Assignee | Epic | Label | Priority
- Sliding indicator beneath active pill: `transform: translateX()` with 200ms cubic-bezier(0.4,0,0.2,1)
- `role="radiogroup"` with `role="radio"` per pill, arrow-key navigation
- Live region announces "Board grouped by [X]" on change
- Responsive fallback: collapses to dropdown `[⊞ Group by: Assignee ▾]` on narrow viewports

### Swimlane Row Design
- Row header: 220px wide, darker blend background, casts right-edge shadow
- Collapse chevron (▾/▸) — 90° rotation, 200ms transition
- Below label: secondary line "N issues" in muted text
- Collapsed state: 48px height, cards hidden via `display: none`
- Row dividers: 2px border-top with subtle top-edge gradient (rgba(255,255,255,0.03))
- Alternating row tint: rgba(255,255,255,0.012) on column cells only

### Row Label Treatment by Grouping Type
- **Assignee**: 32×32 avatar circle (image or hashed-colour initials) + name + count. "Unassigned" gets dashed circle with person icon
- **Priority**: 10px coloured dot with subtle box-shadow glow + priority name + count. Colours: Critical=#ef4444, High=#f97316, Medium=#eab308, Low=#22c55e
- **Label**: Existing label badge components inline + count
- **Epic**: Hexagon/diamond icon in epic accent colour (#8b5cf6 default) + name + count

### Empty States
- Empty cell: dashed border (1.5px), centered italic "No issues", min-height 80px. On drag-hover: solid accent border + tinted background
- Empty lane: collapsed by default showing "0" badge, expandable

### Animation Choreography
- Expand: row height grows (250ms ease), cards stagger fade+slide-up (15ms per card, capped at 5)
- Collapse: all cards fade out (100ms), then row shrinks (200ms ease-in)
- Grouping transition: board cross-fade (150ms out, 220ms in with 6px translateY), pointer-events disabled during
- `@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce)`: all transitions disabled except 100ms opacity fade

### Depth & Layering (dark theme)
| Layer | Element | Shadow |
|-------|---------|--------|
| 0 | Page bg | — |
| 1 | Row cells | — |
| 2 | Row headers (pinned) | 4px 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.35) |
| 3 | Column headers (sticky) | 0 2px 8px rgba(0,0,0,0.4) |
| 4 | Cards | 0 1px 3px rgba(0,0,0,0.3) |
| 5 | Drag ghost | 0 8px 24px rgba(0,0,0,0.5) |

### Scrolling
- Board: single scroll container, `overflow: auto`, `height: calc(100vh - toolbar-height)`
- Column headers sticky top, row headers sticky left — CSS Grid handles both
- Scroll shadow on column headers: `0 4px 16px rgba(0,0,0,0.5)`

### Accessibility
- `role="grid"` with `role="rowgroup"`, `role="row"`, `role="rowheader"`, `role="gridcell"`
- Arrow keys: Up/Down between rows, Left/Right between cells
- Collapse button: `aria-expanded`, `aria-controls`
- Collapsed lanes: `aria-hidden="true"`, removed from tab order
- Focus ring: `outline: 2px solid var(--color-accent); outline-offset: 2px`

### Files to Modify
- `src/client/state.js` — swimlaneGrouping signal (null|assignee|epic|label|priority)
- `src/client/components/Board.jsx` — grouping logic, CSS Grid row-major rendering
- `src/client/components/FilterBar.jsx` — Group-by segmented pill control
- `src/client/components/DroppableColumn.jsx` — adapt for cell-within-row usage
- `src/styles/main.css` — swimlane grid layout, row headers, animations
- New: `src/client/components/SwimlaneRow.jsx`
close_reason: Implemented board swimlanes with group-by control (Assignee, Priority, Type, Label), collapsible rows, empty cell states, CSS Grid layout, and 14 new tests

title: Cycle time tracking
description: Track and display time from open to closed per issue, giving visibility into how long work takes
design:
## UX Design

### Display locations

| Location | What | When |
|---|---|---|
| Board card | Age/cycle time (e.g. `4d`), colour-coded grey/amber/red | Always, bottom-right of card |
| Detail panel | Full timing section with comparison to team median | On card click |
| ThroughputChart | Stats bar (median, p75, trend arrow) + scatter plot overlay | Chart view |

### Formatting
Tiered display: `< 1h`, `6h`, `3d`, `2w`, `6w`. Full precision only in detail panel.

### Colour thresholds (computed from data, not hardcoded)
- Grey (muted): under median — fine
- Amber: at/above median cycle time — worth a look
- Red (muted): above p75 — stale, needs attention
- Thresholds derived from median of last 30 closed issues

### Open/in-progress issues
Show age since created_at with same colour coding. Gives passive board health at a glance. In detail panel show: `Age: 8d (median cycle time: 3d)`.

### Aggregate stats (ThroughputChart header)
- Median cycle time (last 30 closed issues)
- p75 cycle time
- Trend arrow comparing current period median to previous
- No mean — skews badly on small teams

### Scatter plot overlay (ThroughputChart)
- X axis: close date, Y axis: cycle time in days
- Dot per closed issue, horizontal lines at median and p75
- Dots above p75 coloured amber/red
- Toggle on/off, small dots (3-4px), label on hover only

### What NOT to do
- No estimated completion (no data to support it)
- No green for fast (absence of amber/red is sufficient)
- No new views — extend existing ThroughputChart
- No mean — use median throughout
close_reason: Implemented cycle time tracking: duration badges on cards, timing section in detail panel, scatter plot + stats in throughput chart

title: WIP limits
description: Configurable work-in-progress limits per board column with visual highlighting when exceeded
design:
## Implementation

### State
- New signal `wipLimits` in `state.js` — shape: `{ open: number|null, in_progress: number|null, closed: number|null }`
- Default: all `null` (no limits, opt-in per column)

### Display (DroppableColumn.jsx)
- Column header shows count/limit when set: e.g. `In Progress (3/3)`
- Conditional CSS class `column-wip-exceeded` when count >= limit
- Visual highlight (red/orange header background or border) when exceeded

### Settings UI — choose one approach later
**A) Inline edit**: Click the column header count to pop a small input for setting the limit. Minimal UI, discoverable.
**B) Settings panel**: A board-level settings icon that opens a modal/drawer where you configure limits for all columns. More structured, but heavier.
**C) FilterBar control**: Add a WIP config toggle alongside existing filter controls. Consistent with existing UI patterns.

### Persistence — choose one approach later
**A) localStorage**: Simplest, no server changes. Limits persist per browser. Good enough for single-user.
**B) Server config API**: New endpoint + config table. Shareable across devices. Heavier, only needed for multi-user.
**C) URL params**: Shareable/bookmarkable but awkward for config that rarely changes.

### Files touched
- `src/client/state.js` — new signal
- `src/client/components/DroppableColumn.jsx` — count/limit display, exceeded class
- `src/client/main.css` — exceeded styling
- Settings UI component (approach-dependent)

title: Commit linking
description: Show related git commits in the issue detail panel by matching beads issue IDs in commit messages
design:
## Approach: Metadata-based commit linking

### Data flow
1. AI commits code, captures the short hash
2. AI runs: `bd update <issue-id> --metadata '{"commits":["abc1234"]}'`
3. Metadata stored as JSON in dolt `issues.metadata` column
4. bd-eye DetailPanel reads `issue.metadata.commits` and renders them

### Schema
The `metadata` column is a JSON column in dolt. Empty issues have `{}`.
Commit data shape: `{"commits": ["abc1234", "def5678"]}`

### Frontend changes
- DetailPanel: if `metadata.commits` exists and is non-empty, render a 'Commits' section
- Display short hashes, no forge linking needed initially

### AI workflow
- CLAUDE.md instructs agents to record commit hashes via `bd update --metadata` after committing
- Append to existing commits array rather than overwriting
close_reason: Won't do: squash-merge via MR makes individual commit hashes meaningless

title: Cross-project dependencies
description: Visualise and manage dependencies between issues across different beads projects. Beads prefixes already namespace issues
design:
## Design: Cross-project dependencies via metadata

### Storage: `metadata.cross_deps`

Store cross-project dependency refs in the issue metadata JSON column:

```json
{
  "cross_deps": {
    "blocked_by": ["infra-abc", "platform-xyz"],
    "blocks": ["frontend-def"]
  }
}
```

Each side of the relationship stores its half. No schema migration, no new dolt tables — just structured JSON in the existing metadata column.

### Write path

When adding a cross-project dep, write to both project databases:
1. On the local issue: add foreign id to `metadata.cross_deps.blocked_by` (or `blocks`)
2. On the foreign issue: add local id to its `metadata.cross_deps.blocks` (or `blocked_by`)

db-registry already has pools for every project, so both writes are straightforward.

### Read path

When rendering a card or detail panel, merge two sources:
- `dependenciesFor(id)` — in-project deps from the dependencies table (existing)
- `metadata.cross_deps` — cross-project refs

For each foreign ref, do a lightweight fetch from the other project pool (id, title, status) to show whether the blocker is resolved.

### UI

**DetailPanel**: Add a "cross-project dependency" button. Picker flow:
1. Select target project (from db-registry project list)
2. Search/select issue in that project
3. Choose relationship direction (blocked_by / blocks)
4. Writes metadata on both sides

**Card**: Show cross-project blocker count alongside existing blocked_by indicator, visually distinguished (e.g. prefixed with project name or different icon).

**DependencyGraph**: Render foreign nodes with distinct styling (different colour/shape, labelled with project prefix).

### What stays unchanged

- Dolt schema — no migration needed
- Beads CLI — sees opaque JSON in metadata, no changes required
- In-project dependencies — still use the dependencies table as before
- API dependency routes — existing `/issues/:id/dependencies` unchanged

### Sync concern

Both sides must be written atomically-ish. If the foreign project write fails, roll back the local metadata write. Since these are separate dolt databases there is no real transaction across them — best-effort with error handling is pragmatic enough for a P4 feature.
notes:
Cross-project dependencies would let you see and manage dependency links between issues in different beads projects.

## Problem
The dependency graph only shows links within a single project. If an issue is blocked by something in a different project (e.g. an infra task), that blocker is invisible.

## How it would work
- `bd dep add bd-eye-abc infra-def` — the prefix tells beads the dependency crosses projects
- The API resolves foreign-project issues by querying the other project dolt database via db-registry
- Board shows cross-project blockers on cards (foreign prefix highlighted)
- DependencyGraph renders foreign nodes differently (greyed out, different shape, or labelled with project name)
- DetailPanel dependency section shows the foreign issue title/status even though it lives elsewhere

## Why complexity:high, impact:low
Touches multiple layers (beads CLI, API dependency routes, multi-project db-registry, several UI components), but most teams keep dependencies within a single project. Power-user feature — leave on backlog unless cross-project blocking pain is actually felt.

title: Interactive dependency graph
description: Interactive visualisation on the Deps view using a graph renderer like d3-dag or elkjs. The dependency data is already served by the API
design:
## Design: Interactive Dependency Graph

**Library**: dagre (layout-only, ~40KB gzipped) — purpose-built DAG layout, no framework opinions, Preact-compatible.

**Architecture**: SVG rendering with dagre providing node coordinates and edge spline paths. Keeps existing dark theme CSS variables and status border colors.

**Interactions**:
- Pan: pointer drag on SVG background
- Zoom: mouse wheel with cursor-anchored scaling (0.3x–3.0x)
- Node hover: highlight connected edges, dim others
- Tooltip: positioned div overlay showing issue title/status
- Fit-to-view button to reset transform
- Click nodes to select (existing behaviour)

**Component structure**:
- FocusView: unchanged
- FullGraphView: replace internals with:
  - useGraphLayout(issues, deps) — runs dagre, returns positioned graph (memoized)
  - useGraphTransform() — pan/zoom state via useReducer
  - GraphEdges: cubic bezier paths from dagre control points
  - GraphNodes: existing status-colored rect+text nodes
  - Fit button + tooltip overlay

**Preact note**: wheel event listener via useEffect+ref with { passive: false } for preventDefault.
close_reason: Replaced hand-rolled SVG with dagre-powered interactive dependency graph: pan/zoom, edge highlighting on hover, tooltips, fit-to-view button
